item.title: Beogram 4000: A Fun Evening with a Prematurely Activating Solenoid
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 restoration is progressing well. Rebuilding the deck led to a successful initial power-up where the carriage moved to the correct position, but the arm wouldn’t lower. A visual inspection showed a disconnected thin grey wire from the SK3054 NPN power transistor (0TR4). Tracing the wiring and consulting the schematic revealed that the grey wire connected to the transistor’s emitter, responsible for bypassing a current-limiting resistor (7R1) during the arm’s initial descent...

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Electrolytic Capacitors on the PCBs
item.description:
I began restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) by replacing all the electrolytic capacitors on the printed circuit boards with high-quality 105C capacitors. I made sure to use components from reputable Japanese brands like Nichicon and Rubycon, sourcing them through trusted distributors like Newark and Mouser. The process was straightforward, aside from uncovering a spider web (and its architect) beneath the main PCB. This restoration project also highlighted the existence of at least two different solenoid control circuits within the 5513 series...

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the Detector Arm Light Bulb, Discussion of the Circuit and Relevant Oscilloscope Traces
item.description:

item.title: Beogram 4000: An Entertaining Afternoon Exploring the Record Detection Circuit
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, a problem arose with its record detection system. While it functioned correctly at the 12-inch LP position, it frequently failed to detect records at the 7-inch singles position. This malfunction was observed when the turntable, starting without a record on the platter, bypassed the LP position but stopped at the singles position.
